utterances: Next week, Julie Rovner(ph) is the Political Junkie.
Right.
And, yeah, and Julie Rovner has a plan that we should all talk about.
We should all talk about, yeah.
But the point is I think that, politically, it was very interesting to see her - now again, we're talking more about what it does for Hillary Clinton and her negatives.
But I think it comes at a very interesting time in her campaign.
Now, let's get a caller on.
This is Marianne(ph).
Marianne with us from Antrim in New Hampshire?
Yes, hi.
Go ahead, please.
I was wondering if Mr. Rudin would comment upon Barack Obama's new plan released yesterday for tax fairness for the middle class?
Ken?
Well, it's an issue obviously that, you know, all the Democrats are very, very concerned about.
He's talked about how, you know, the tax fairness is an issue that Republicans have taken as their own for the longest, longest time.
But Obama did announce his plan yesterday for this, the tax plan.
It's -obviously, it's one of the things that he needs to do because he seems to be loading plans left and right and there seem to be little headway for him in the poll.
You look at - again, we keep talking about how silly national polls are to talk about.
But we're getting closer and closer to Iowa and New Hampshire than we have in previous weeks obviously.
And the fact is that he still remains double digits behind Hillary Clinton.
I know he's proposing this.
He also criticized Hillary Clinton's plan about health care as well, he said that you need somebody as a consensus builder who could do that.
And he questions whether Hillary Clinton's the person to do that.
But ultimately, he's going to have to make some headway if voters are going to take him more seriously.

And a new ad out today in Iowa, where he's doing considerably better than in the national polls, where he talks about, you know, the cynics in Washington roll their eyes when I say, we'd have to make change.
We can really make change in Washington.
So we'll have to see if that has an impact as well.
Thanks for the call, Marianne.
Let's go to - this is Raquel(ph).
Raquel with us from Baton Rouge, Louisiana.
Hey, Ken, how are you doing?
Go ahead, please.
Mr. O'SHAY: About two straight years.
Two years?
Yeah.
Great.
I was calling to find out what Ken thinks about the latest information about the four Republican frontrunners for the presidential - for the president.
And they have indicated that they will not attend the all-American presidential forum by Tavis Smiley on - next week at Morgan State.
And I wanted to find out from Ken what does he think this message is being sent to the African-American voter, as well as to their issues?
Well, that's a good question.
Tavis Smiley of PBS did have a Democratic forum and all the candidates showed up.

And there was some comments by Tavis Smiley over the last couple of weeks that basically was almost daring the Republicans not to show up, almost critical of them in advance, which you usually don't see that in the debate moderator.
But, you know, the same Republicans who are boycotting the Tavis Smiley debate - forum are also debating a series of traditional values forum that we've seen.
There was one the other day at Fort Lauderdale, there's one this weekend in South Carolina.
And the top four candidates are boycotting that as well.
So, I mean, two groups that they may be alienating African-American voters who have never really voted a Republican in recent years.
But also social conservatives, they've not gone to that either.
Some feel that they are just too many of these debates and they feel they want to prepare for the big ones.

But there is a message to African-American voters and Tavis Smiley will no doubt say that next Thursday during the event in Morgan State in Baltimore, saying that they're taking, you know, they're just ignoring the black vote.
Raquel, thanks for the call.
And before we go, Ken, we should note that there is a new presidential candidate on the Republican side who is himself African-American.
Well, yes, it's Alan Keyes.
God has told him to announce, you know, I remember where I was when the U.S.
won the hockey Olympic medal in 1980.
This is almost as dramatic for me.
Alan Keyes is running for president.
You know, he ran in 1996, 2000, gotten nowhere.
He ran against Barack Obama for the Senate.
So maybe, it was set for a rerun.
Of going nowhere?
After he foughtâ€¦
Lincoln Douglas maybe.
No.
No.
Alan Keyes has registered as a presidential candidate for the Republican Party.
We'll have to see what impact, if any, he makes.
Ken Rudin, thanks very much for being with us.
Thanks, Neal.
Ken Rudin, NPR's Political Junkie.
You can read his column at npr.org.
And join us again next Wednesday for another edition of the Political Junkie.
I'm Neal Conan.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
This is DAY TO DAY.
And these are the words of French writer Alexis de Tocqueville.
The American has no time to tie himself to anything.
He grows accustomed only to change and regards it as a natural state of mind.
De Tocqueville's classic work ""Democracy in America"" was published in 1835.
It is still widely considered the best description of American political life ever.
De Tocqueville was born 200 years ago today.
NPR's Eric Weiner has this birthday greeting.
Dear Alexis, 200 years old, I can hardly believe it.
It seems like just yesterday you were traipsing through a young United States, from upstate New York to Louisiana, observing us, knowing us better than we know ourselves.
You'll be happy to hear that your books are as popular as ever.

You're on every politician's bookshelf, right next to Machiavelli's ""The Prince"" and Sun Tzu's ""The Art of War."" I don't know if they've actually read you, Alexis--940 pages is a bit daunting--but they sure love to quote you, and from both ends of the political spectrum.
Ronald Reagan invoked your name often, and so did Bill Clinton.
Here he is delivering his 1995 State of the Union address.
(Soundbite of 1995 State of the Union address)

If you go back to the beginning of this country, the great strength of America, as de Tocqueville pointed out when he came here a long time ago, has always been our ability to associate with people who were different from ourselves.
And it's not just politicians who invoke you, Alexis.
Anti-war activists now look to you for ammunition, carting out what you said about war and democracy.
All those who seek to destroy the liberties of a democratic nation ought to know that war is the surest and shortest means to accomplish it.
Then again, those in favor of the war in Iraq cite you also.
Gregory Fossedal, founding chairman of the de Tocqueville Institution, explains why people love to borrow your words.
It's like a smorgasbord.

They like to walk through and pick out, `Oh, well, here are the Tocqueville rutabagas, and that supports my idea, so now I can quote a great Frenchman, Alexis de Tocqueville, as supporting HR 1047,' or the war in Iraq or whatever cause they're enlisting him for.
What does it say that the best book written on American democracy was written by a French aristocrat?
(Laughs) It is sometimes easier to see things when you are an outsider who visits.
You can abstract from and observe things within a family that, to the family itself, are just happening instinctively or unconsciously.
Maybe he's right, Alexis.
How else to explain your many accurate predictions, like the one about the US and Russia fighting for global supremacy?
We won that one.
The spirit of volunteerism that you so admired in America is still alive today.
And we still read voraciously, as you noted, but now there's this thing called TiVo and DVDs and video games.
It's difficult to explain; you'd have to see them.
Of course, nobody's perfect, Alexis.
You did get some things wrong, like your prediction that America would never produce truly artists and scientists.
Oops.

But it's your birthday, so I won't dwell on the few things you got wrong when there's so much about America you got right, like when you noted that in no other country in the world is the love of property keener than in the US.
Boy, is that true.
In fact, there's this three-bedroom, two-bath colonial you might be interested in.
It needs some work, but--well, never mind.
Happy birthday, Alexis.
Yours truly, Eric Weiner, NPR News.
Mr.
O'SHAY: Deep cover.
Yeah.
We bought from, oh, a lot of people.
We solved a lot of other crimes and learned an awful lot about people.
And during that entire time, you spent most of your time hanging out with the biker people and...
Mr.
O'SHAY: Yeah, we did.
And solved a lot of other crimes.
And we did it quietly.
There was no scandals or anything involved.
There was no, you know, seeking glory or anything, just something that happened and it worked.
And we did it.
(Soundbite of music)
